bibl.title: Encyclopaedia Britannica: a dictionary of arts, sciences, and general literature

publisher.orgName: University of California Libraries, California Digital Library

listBibl.head: Alternate image sources for this edition:
listBibl.desc: Alternate images of the same print editions were substituted when the primary source had unusable images for those pages.
listBibl.bibl: Hathi Trust, from print source at the University of Michigan: vol. 14, pp. 34-35; vol. 15, pp. 170-171.

list.item: Encoding has been done using the recommendations for Level 3 of the "TEI in Libraries Guidelines."
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Print page headers and side descriptions are not included.
OCR successfully reproduced simple tables, but complex tabular data is not captured dependably and the results should not be relied upon.
OCR was not able to successfully reproduce math and chemical formulas. The uncorrected results remain in the text.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, smallcaps, strikethrough, subscript, superscript, underline. The following print styles are ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is indicated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for future entry subsections.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze using machine-learning methods.

Subject keywords are added to teiHeader for each entry; they were generated by the HIVE2 automated vocabulary server, created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: This release reproduces the text matter for all entries. It does not include images, front- or back-matter. The reproduction of tables and formulae is unreliable.

prefixDef.p: URIs with the prefix fastgeo: point to terms in the OCLC FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology) Geographical subject heading schema derived from the Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH).

URIs with the prefix fasttopic: point to terms in the OCLC FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology) Topical subject heading schema derived from the Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH).
URIs with the prefix lcsh1910: point to subject terms in Subject Headings Used in the Dictionary Catalogues of the Library of Congress, 2 vols., Library of Congress, 1910.
URIs with the prefix ht: point to page images in the Hathi Trust.
URIs with the prefix ia: point to page images in the Internet Archive.
URIs with the prefix nls: point to page images in the National Library of Scotland.

listChange.change: v1.1. Isolates one entry; corrects "B.c." and variants; replaces "bom" with "born", removed 783 instances of extra space before semicolon. Separates metadata in teiHeader into two separate facets: FAST Topical and FAST Geographical.

div.p: BUCKLAND, The Very Rev. William (1784-ι856), the eldest son of the Rev. Charles Buckland, rector of Templeton and Trusham, in the county of Devon, was born at Axminster in Devonshire, 12th March 1784. He was educated at the ancient Grammar School of Tiverton, and at Winchester, and in 1801 was elected by examination a scholar of Corpus Christi College, Oxford. In 1805 he proceeded to the degree of B. A., and in 1808 he was elected a fellow of his college. From early boyhood he had exhibited a strong taste for natural science; his innate bias was at this time stimulated by the lectures of Dr Kidd on mineralogy and chemistry, and his attention was thus more especially drawn to the then infant science of geology. He now devoted himself systematically to an examination of the geological structure of Great Britain, making many excursions on horseback, and investigating both the order of superposition of the strata and the characters of the organic remains which they contained. In 1813, on the resignation of Dr Kidd, he was appointed reader in mineralogy in Oxford; and the interest excited by his lectures was so great that in 1819 a readership in geology was founded and especially endowed by the Treasury, Dr Bucklaud being the first holder of the new appointment. In 1818 Dr Buckland was elected a fellow of the Royal Society, and in 1824 he was chosen president of the Geological Society of London, of which he had long been a fellow. In 1825. he resigned his fellowship at Corpus, and was presented by his college to the living of Stoke Charity, near Whitchurch, Hants, and in the same year he was appointed by Lord Liverpool to a canonry of the cathedral of Christ Church, Oxford. In the same year, also, he married Mary, the eldest daughter of Mr Benjamin Morland of Sheepstead House, near Abingdon, Berks, by whose high intellectual abilities and excellent judgment he was materially assisted in his literary labours. During the succeeding twenty years he laboured diligently in various departments of his favourite science, visiting many interesting localities, both at home and abroad, accumulating extensive collections, and communicating numerous memoirs to learned societies. In 1845 he was apppointed by Sir Robert Peel to the vacant deanery of Westminster, and was soon after inducted to the living of Islip, near Oxford, a preferment attached to the deanery. In 1849 his health began to give way under the increasing pressure of his multifarious duties; and the latter years of his life were overshadowed by a long and serious illness, arising from disease of the base of the skull, which compelled him to live in retirement, to the deep regret of a wide circle of friends and acquaintances. He died 24th August 1856, at the advanced age of seventy-three, and he was buried in a spot which he had himself chosen in Islip churchyard. Dr Buckland was a man many-sided in his abilities, and of a singularly wide range of attainments. Apart from his published works and memoirs in connection with the special department of geology, he accomplished in other directions much that entitles him to remembrance. Few men, indeed, ever more laboriously and consistently devoted a long life to the advancement of the cause of truth and to the benefit of their fellow-men. In addition to the work entailed upon him by the positions which he at different times held in the Church of England, he entered with great enthusiasm into many practical questions connected with agricultural and sanitary science, and various social and even medical problems. As a teacher he possessed powers of the highest order; and the university of Oxford is enriched by the large and valuable private collections, illustrative of geology and mineralogy, which he amassed in the course of his active lite, and which are now known as the “Buckland Museum.” It is, how ever, upon his published scientific works that Dr Buckland’s great reputation is mainly based. His first great w ork was the well known Reliquioe Diluvianoe,or Observations on the Organic Remains attesting the Action of a Universal Deluge, published in 1823, in which he supplemented his former observations on the remains of extinct animals discovered in the cavern of Kirkdale in Yorkshire, and expounded his views as to the bearing of these and similar cases on the Biblical account of the Deluge. Thirteen years after the publication of the Reliquia,, Dr Buckland was called upon, in accordance with the will of the earl cf Bridgewater, to write one of that remarkable series of works, known as the Bridgewater Treatises. The design of these treatises was to exhibit the “power, wisdom, and goodness of God, as manifested in the creation,” and none of them was of greater value, as evinced by its vitality, than that on geology and mineralogy. Originally published in 1836, it has gone through four editions, and though not a “manual” of geological science, it still possesses a high value as a rich storehouse of geological and palaeontological facts bearing upon the particular argument which it was designed to illustrate, ,-j

Of Dr Buckland’s numerous original contributions to the sciences of Geology and Palaeontology, the following may be mentioned as being the most important:—1. “On the Structure of the Alps and adjoining parts of the Continent, and their relation to the Secondary and Transition Rocks of England” (Annals of Phil. 1821); 2. “Account of an Assemblage of Fossil Teeth and Bones of Elephant, Rhinoceros, Hippopotamus, Bear, Tiger, and Hyena, and Sixteen other Animals, discovered in a Cave at Kirkdale in Yorkshire” (Phil. Trans'); 3. “On a Series of Specimens from the Plastic Clay near Reading, Berks, with observations on the Formation to which these Beds belong” (Trans. Geol. Soc. Lond); 4. “On the Megalosaurus or Great Fossil Lizard of Stonesfield” (Ibid); 5. “On the Cycade-oideae, a Family of Plants found in the Oolite Quarries of the Isle of Portland ’ ' (Ibid); 6. “On the Discovery of a New Species of Ptérodactyle in the Lias of Lyme Regis” (Ibid); 7. “On the Discovery of Coprolites or Fossil Faeces in the Lias of Lyme Regis, and in other Formations” (Ibid); 8. “On the Evidences of Glaciers in Scotland and the North of England” (Proc. Geol. Soc. Lond); 9. “On the SouthWestern Coal District of England (joint paper with Mr Conybeare, Trans. Geol. Soc. Lond); 10. “On the Geology of the eighbour-hood of Weymout⅛, and the adjacent parts of the Coast of Dorset” (joint paper with Sir H. de La Beche, Trans. Geol. Soc. Lond.)
